newsitem.title: USA: U.S. mortgage-backeds creep higher with T-bonds.
newsitem.headline: U.S. mortgage-backeds creep higher with T-bonds.

text.p: U.S. mortgage-backed securities held on to modest gains near the end of a quiet Tuesday session.
Overall, yield spreads to Treasuries were unchanged to slightly wider, traders said. And volume was relatively thin.
Among key coupons, Ginnie Mae 30-year 8.0 percent paper rose 3/32 to 100-19/32 bid, yielding 120 basis points over the five-year Treasury note.
Comparable Fannie Mae current coupons were up 3/32 at 100-18/32 bid, while Freddie Mac paper rose 4/32 to 100-25/32 bid.
The five-year Treasury note was up 5/32 at 99-19/32 bid to yield 6.72 percent, while the 10-year Treasury note was 7/32 higher, to yield 6.88 percent.
Looking ahead, traders said market fears of higher interest rates will flatten the Treasury yield curve, generating more volatility and wider spreads in mortgages.
"Volatility should be bad for mortgages," said one trader in New York. "I think if you look at it, the yield curve should flatten and mortgages should widen," he said.
The trader said overall pass-through prices are expensive, adding that they "have come too far too fast."
Another market participant said he had witnessed numerous odd-lot paper exchanging hands. "Other than that, it's been quiet," he said.
